editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Satiro-mastix. Or the untrussing of the humorous poet. As it hath been presented publicly, by the right honourable, the lord chamberlain his servants; and privately, by the children of Paul's. By Thomas Dekker.
Non recito cviquam nisi amicis idque coactus ▪
London, printed for Edward white, and are to be sold at his shop, near the little North door of Paul's church, at the sign of the gun. 1602.

div.head: Ad detractorem.
div.l: Non potes in nugas dicere plurameas,
Ipse ego quam dixi. — qui se mir antur, in illos
Virus habe: nos hae novimus esse nihil.

div.head: To the world.
div.p: World, I was once resolved to be round with thee, because of know 'tis thy fashion to be round with everybody : but the wind shifting his point, the vein turned: yet because thou wilt sit as judge of all matters (Though for thy labour thou wear'st Midas's ears, and are monstrum horrendum, inform: ingens cvi lumen ademptum; whose great Polyphemian eye is put out) I care not much if I make description (Before thy universality) of that terrible poetomachia, lately commenced between Horace the second, and a band of lean-witted poetasters. They have been at high words, and so high, that the ground could not serve them, but (For want of chopins) have stalked upon stages.

Horace haled his poetasters to the bar, the poetasters untrussed Horace: how worthily either, or how wrongfully, (World) leave it to the jury: Horace (Questionless) made himself believe, that his Burgonian wit might desperately challenge all comers, and that none durst take up the foils against him: it's likely, if he had not so believed, he had not been so deceived, for he was answered at his own weapon: and if before Apollo himself (Who is coronator poetarum) an inquisition should be taken touching this lamentable merry murdering of innocent poetry: all mount Helicon
〈…〉

I could here (Even with the feather of my pen) wipe off other ridiculous imputations: but my best way to answer them, is to laugh at them: only thus much I protest (And swear by the divinest part of true poesy) that (Howsoever the limbs of my naked lines may be and I know have have been, tortured on the rack) they are free from conspiring the least disgrace to any man, but only to our new Horace; neither should this ghost of Tucca, have walked up and down Poule's churchyard, but that he was razed up (In print) by new exorcisms. World, if thy hugeness will believe this: do, if not, I care not: for I dedicate my book not to thy greatness, but to the greatness of thy scorn: defying which, let that mad dog Detraction
bite till his teeth be worn to the stumps: envy feed thy snakes so fat with poison till they burst: world, let all thy adders shoot out their hydra-headed-forked stings, ha, ha, Nanci; if none will take my part, (As I desire none) yet I thank thee (Thou true Venusian Horace) for these good words thou givest me: populus me sibylat at mihi plaudo. World farewell.

div.head: Ad lectorem.
div.p: In steed of the trumpets sounding thrice, before the play begin: it shall not be amiss (For him that will read) first to behold this short comedy of errors, and where the greatest enter, to give them in stead of a hiss, a gentle correction.
In letter C. page. 1. for, whom I adorned as subjects: read, whom I adored as, etc.
In letter c pa 3. for, I'll starve thence poor: read, I'll starve their poor, etc.
In letter c pa 6. for, her white cheeks with her dregs and bottom: read, her white cheeks with the dregs and, etc.
In the same page, for, strike off the head of sin: read, strike off the swollen head, etc.
In the same page, for, that of five hundred, four hundred five read, that of five hundred: four.
In letter G. pa 1. for, this interchanging of languages: read, this interchange of language.
In letter L. pa 5. for, and stinging insolence should: read, and stinking insolence, etc.

div.head: The untrussing of the humorous poet.
div.stage: Enter two gentlewomen strewing of flowers.

sp.p: Come bedfellow come, strew apace, strew, strew: in good troth 'tis pity that these flowers must be trodden under feet as they are like to be anon.

Pity, alack pretty heart, thou art sorry to see any good thing fall to the ground: pity? no more pity, than to see an innocent maidenhead delivered up to the ruffling of her new-wedded husband. Beauty is made for use, and he that will not use a sweet soul well, when she is under his fingers I pray Venus he may never kiss a fair and a delicate, soft, red 'Plump-lip.
Amen, and that's torment enough.

Pity? come fool fling them about lustily; flowers never die a sweeter death, than when they are smothered to death in a lover's bosom, or else pave the high ways, over which these pretty, simpering, jetting things, called brides, must trip.
I pray thee tell me, why do they use at weddings to furnish all places thus, with sweet herbs and flowers?
One reason is, because 'tis — o a most sweet thing to lie with a man.
I think 'tis a oh more more more more sweet to lie with a woman.

I warrant all men are of thy mind: another reason is, because they stick like the scutcheons of madam chastity, on the sable ground, weeping in their stalks, and winking with their yellow-sunk eyes, as loath to behold the lamentable fall of a maidenhead: what senseless thing in all the house, that is not now as melancholy, as a new set-up schoolmaster?
Troth I am.

Troth I think thou mournest, because thou'st missed thy turn, I do by the quiver of Cupid: you see the torches melt themselves away in tears: the instruments wear their heart strings out for sorrow: and the silver ewers weep most pitiful rose-water: five or six pair of the white innocent wedding gloves, did in my sight choose rather to be torn in pieces than to be drawn on; and look this rosemary, (A fatal herb) this deadman's nosegay, has crept in amongst these flowers to deck th'invisible corse of the bride's maidenhead, when (O how much do we poor wenches suffer) about eleven or twelve, or one o'clock at midnight at furthest, it descends to purgatory, to give notice that Caelestine (Heigh ho) will never come to lead apes in hell.
I see by thy sighing thou wilt not.
If I had as many maidenheads, as I have hairs on my head I'd venture them all rather then to come into so hot a place; prithee strew thou, for my little arms are weary.
I am sure thy little tongue is not.

No faith that's like a woman bitten with fleas, it never lies still: fie upon't, what a miserable thing 'tis to be a noble bride, there's such delays in rising, in fitting gowns, in tiring, in pinning rebates, in poking, in dinner, in supper, in revels, and last of all in cursing the poor nodding fiddlers, for keeping mistress Bride so long up from sweeter revels; that, o I could
never endure to put it up without much bickering.
Come thou'rt an odd wench, hark, hark, music? nay then the bride's up.

Is she up? nay then I see she has been down: lord ha mercy on us, we women fall and fall still, and when we have husbands we play upon them like virginal jacks, they must rise and fall to our humours, or else they'll never get any good strains of music out of us; but come now, have at it for a maidenhead.

div.stage: As they strew, enter sir, Quintilian Shorthose with Peter flash and two or three serving-men, with lights.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Come knaves, night begins to be like myself, an old man; day plays the thief and steals upon us; oh well done wenches, well done, well done, you have covered all the stony way to church with flowers, 'tis well, 'tis well, there's an emblem too, to be made out of these flowers and stones, but you are honest wenches, in, in, in.
When we come to your years, we shall learn what honesty is, come pew-fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Is the music come yet? so much to do! Is't come?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Have the merry knaves pulled their fiddle cases over their instruments ears?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: As soon as ere they entered our gates, the noise went, before they came near the great hall, the faint hearted villiacoes sounded at least thrice.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Thou shouldst have revived them with a cup of burned wine and sugar; sirrah, you, horsekeeper, go, bid them curry their strings: is my daughter up yet?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Up sir? she was seen up an hour ago .

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: She's an early stirrer, ah sirrah.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: She'll be a late stirrer soon at night sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Go too Peter flash, you have a good sudden flash of brain, your wits husky, and no marvel, for 'tis like one of our comedians beards, stillith stubble: about your business, and look you be nimble to fly from the wine, or the nimble wine will catch you by the nose.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: If your wine play with my nose sir, I'll knock's coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Do Peter, and wear it for thy labour; is my son in law sir Walter Terell ready yet?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ready sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: One of you attend him: stay flash, where's the note of the guests you have invited?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Here sir, I'll pull all your guests out of my bosom; the men that will come, I have crossed, but all the gentlewomen have at the tail of the last letter a prick, because you may read them the better.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: My spectacles, light, light, knaves: sir Adam Prickshaft, thou hast crossed him, he'll come.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I had much ado sir, to draw sir Adam Prickshaft home, because I told him 'twas early, but he'll come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Justice crop, what will he come?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: He took physic yesterday sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: O then crop cannot come.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: O lord yes, sir yes 'twas but to make more room in his crop for your good cheer, crop will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Widow Mineuer.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: She's pricked you see sir, and will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Sir Vaughan ap Rees, o he's crossed twice, so, so, so, than all these ladies, that fall downwards here, will come I see, and all these gentlemen that stand right before them.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: All will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p:
Well said, here, write them out again, and put the men from the women; and Peter, when we are at church
bring wine and cakes, be light and nimble good flash, for your burden will be but light.

div.stage: Enter sir Adam a light before him.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam
sp.p: Prickshaft good morrow, good morrow: go, in, in, in, to the bridegroom, taste a cup of burned wine this morning, 'twill make you fly the better all the day after.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: You are an early stirrer sir Quintilian Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: I am so, it behoves me at my daughter's wedding, in, in, in; fellow put out thy torch, and put thyself into my buttery, the torch burns ill in thy hand, the wine will burn better in thy belly, in in.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Ware there, room for sir Adam Prickshaft: your worship —

div.stage: Enter sir Vaughan and mistress Minever.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Sir Vaughan and widow, Minever, welcome, welcome, a thousand times: my lips mistress widow shall bid you good morrow, in, in, one to the bridegroom, the other to the bride.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughen.
sp.p: Why then sir Quintilian Shorthose, I will step into mistress bride, and widow Minever, shall go upon m. bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.p: No pardon, for by my truly sir Vaughan, I'll ha' no dealings with any m. bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: In widow in, in honest knight in.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: I will usher you mistress widow.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Light there for sir Vaughan; your good worship —

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: Drink that shilling ma. Peter flash, in your guts and belly.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I'll not drink it down sir, but I'll turn it into that which shall run down, o merrily!

div.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, Demetrius, and others with ladies, lights before them.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Good morrow to these beauties, and gentlemen, that have ushered this troop of ladies to my daughter's wedding, welcome, welcome all; music? nay then the bridegroom's coming, where are these knaves here?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: All here sir.

div.stage: Enter Terill, sir Adam, sir Vaughan, Coelestine, Minever, and other ladies and attendant. 〈◊〉 lights.

sp.speaker: Teri.
sp.p: Good morrow ladies and fair troops of gallants, that have deposed the drowsy King of sleep, to crown our train with your rich presences, I salute you all;
sp.l: Each one share thanks from thanks in general.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Good morrow m. bridegroom, mistress bride.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good morrow m. bride groom.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Gallants I shall entreat you to prepare,
For masks and revels to defeat the night,
Our sovereign will in person grace our marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: What will the King be here?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Father he will.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin
sp.p: Where be these knaves? More rosemary and gloves, gloves, gloves: choose gentlemen; ladies put on soft skins upon the skin of softer hands; so, so: come mistress bride take you your place, the old men first, and then the bachelors; maids with the bride, widows and wives together, the priest's at church, 'tis time that we march thither

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Dear blunt at our return from church, take pains to step to Horace, for our nuptial songs; now father when you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p:
Agreed, set on, come good sir Vaughan, must we
lead the way?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Peter you go too fast for mistress pride: so, gingerly, gingerly; I muse why sir Adam Prickshaft sticks so short behind?

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: He follows close, not too fast, hold up knaves,
Thus we lead youth to church, they us to graves.

div.stage: Horrace sitting in a study behind a curtain, a candle by him burning, books lying confusedly: to himself.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To thee whose forehead swells with roses,
Whose most haunted bower
Gives life and sent to every flower,
Whose most adored name encloses,
Things abstruse, deep and divine,
Whose yellow tresses shine,
Bright as Eoan fire.
O me thy priest inspire.
For I to thee and thine immortal name,
In-in-in golden tunes,
For I to thee and thine immortal name —
In sacred raptures flowing, flowing, swimming, swimming:
In sacred raptures swimming,
Immortal name, game, dame, tame, lame, lame, lame,
Pux, hath, shame, proclaim, o —
In sacred raptures flowing, will proclaim, not —
Oh me thy priest inspire!
For I to thee and thine immortal name,
In flowing numbers filled with spright and flame,
Good, good, in flowing numbers filled with spright and flame.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Horace, Horace, my sweet ningle, is always in labour when I come, the nine muses be his midwives I pray Jupiter: ningle.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame, to thee.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: To me? I pledge thee sweet ningle, by Bacchus quaffing bowl, I thought thou'dst drunk to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: It must have been in the divine liquor of Parnassus, then in which, I know you would scarce have pledged me, but come sweet rogue, sit, sit, sit.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Over head and ears i'faith? I have a sackful of news for thee, thou shalt plague some of them, if God send us life and health together.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: It's no matter, empty thy sack anon, but come here first honest rogue, come.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Is't good, is't good ▪ pure Helicon ha?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Damn me if't be not the best that ever came from me, if I have any judgement, look sir, 'tis an epithalamium for sir Walter Terrill's wedding, my brains have given assault to it but this morning.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Then I hope to see them fly out like gunpowder ere night.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Nay good rogue mark, for they are the best lines that ever I drew.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Here's the best leaf in England, but on, on, I'll but tune this pipe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Mark, to thee whose forehead swells with roses.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: O sweet, but will there be no exceptions taken, because forehead and swelling comes together?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Push, away, away, it's proper, besides 'tis an elegancy to say the fore head swells.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Nay an't be proper, let it stand for god's love.

sp.speaker: H●r.
sp.l: Whose most haunted bower,
Gives life and sent to every flower,
Whose most adored name encloses,
Things abstruse, deep and divine.
Whose yellow tresses shine,
bright as Eoan fire.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: O pure, rich, there's heat in this, on, on.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bright as Eoan fire,
Oh me thy priest inspire!
For I to thee and thine immortal name — mark this.
In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.l: I marry, there's sprite and flame in this.

sp.speaker: Ho●.
sp.l: A pox, a this tobacco.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Would this case were my last, if I did not mark, nay all's one, I have always a consort of pipes about me, mine ingle is all fire and water; I marked, by this candle (Which is none of God's angels) I remember, you started back at sprite and flame.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For I to thee and thine immortal name,
In flowing numbers filled with sprite and flame,
To thee love's mightiest King,
Hymen o Hymen does our chaste muse sing.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: There's music in this;

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mark now dear Asinius.
Let these virgins quickly see thee,
Leading out the bride,
Though their blushing cheeks they hide,
Yet with kisses will they fee thee,
To untie their virgin zone,
They grieve to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: So do I by Venus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yet with kisses will they fee thee, my muse has marched (Dear rogue) no farder yet: but how is't? how is't? nay prithee good Asinius deal plainly, do not flatter me, come, how? —

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: If I have any judgement:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Nay look you sir, and then follow a troop of other rich and laboured conceits, o the end shall be admirable! but how is't sweet Bubo, how, how?

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: If I have any judgement, 'tis the best stuff that ever dropped from thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You ha' seen my acrostics?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: I'll put up my pipes and then I'll see any thing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Thou'st a copy of mine odes to, hast not Bubo?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Your odes? O that which you spoken by word a mouth at th'ordinary, when Musco the gull cried mew at it:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: A pox on him poor brainless rook: and you remember, I told him his wit lay at pawn with his new satin suit, and both would be lost, for not fetching home by a day.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: At which he would fain ha' blushed but that his painted cheeks would not let him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Nay sirrah the palinode, which I mean to stitch to my revels, shall be the best and ingenious piece that ever I sweat for; stay rogue, I'll fat thy spleen and make it plump with laughter.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Shall I? faith ningle, shall I see thy secrets?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Puh my friends.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: But what farthel's that? what farthel's that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Fardel, away, 'tis my packet; here lies entombed the loves of knights and Earls, here 'tis, here 'tis, here 'tis, sir Walter Terrill's letter to me, and my answer to him: I no sooner opened his letter, but there appeared to me three glorious angels, whom I adorned, as subjects do their sovereigns: the honest knight angles for my acquaintance, with such golden baits — but why dost laugh my good rogue? how is my answer, prithee, how, how?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Answer, as God judge me ningle, for thy wit thou mayst answer any justice of peace in England I warrant; thou writest in a most goodly big hand too, I like that, and readest as legibly as some that have been saved by their neck-verse.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: But how dost like the knights inditing?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p:
If I have any judgement; a pox o't, here's worshipful
lines indeed, here's stuff: but sirrah ningle, of what fashion is this knight's wit, of what block?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Why you see; well, well, an ordinary ingenuity, a good wit for a knight, you know how, before God I am haunted with some the most pitiful dry gallants.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Troth so I think; good pieces of landscape, show best afar off.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, excellent sumpter horses, carry good clothes; but honest rogue, come, what news, what news abroad? I have heard a the horses walking a'th top of Paul's.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Haye? why then captain Tucca rails upon you most preposterously behind your back, did you not hear him ▪

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A pox upon him: by the white and soft hand of Minerva, I'll make him the most ridiculous: dam me if I bring not's humor ath' stage: and — scurvy limping tongued captain, poor greasy buff jerkin, hang him: 'tis out of his element to traduce me: I am too well ranked Asinius to be stabbed with his dudgeon wit: sirrah, I'll compose an epigram, upon him, shall go thus —

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Nay I ha' more news, there's Crispinus and his jorneyman poet Demetrius Faninus too, they swear they'll bring your life and death upon th' stage like a bricklayer in a play.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Bubo they must press more valiant wits than their own to do it: me ath' stage? ha, ha, I'll start thence poor copper-lace workmasters, that dare play me: I can bring (And that they quake at) a prepared troop of gallants, who for my sake shall distaste every unsalted line, in their fly-blown comedies

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Nay what's certain, I'll bring 100. gallants of my rank

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: That same Crispinus is the silliest dor, and Faninus the slightest cobweb-lawn pierce of a poet, o God! why should I care what every dor doth buzz. Incredulous ears, it is a crown to me. That the best judgements can report me wronged.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: I am one of them that can report it:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I think but what they are, and am not moved.
The one a light voluptuous reveller,
The other, a strange arrogating puff,
Both impudent, and arrogant enough.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: 'Slid do not Criticus revel in these lines, ha ningle ha?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes, they're mine own.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Horace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Horace, not up yet;

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Peace, tread softly, hide my paper; who's this so early?
sp.l: Some of my rooks, some of my gulls?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Horace, Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Who's there? stray, tread softly: what Terill on my life: who's there? my gown sweet rogue, so, come up, come in.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Good morrow Horace.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: O, God save you gallants.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Asinius Bubo well met.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Nay I hope so Crispinus, yet I was sick a quarter of a year a got of a vehement great toothache: a pox o't, it bit me vilely, as God same la I knew 'twas you by your knocking so soon as I saw you; Demetrius Fannius, will you take a whiff this morning? I have tickling gear now, here's that will play with your nose, and a pipe of mine own scouring too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, and a hogshead too of your own, but that will never be scoured clean I fear.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p:
I burned my pipe yesternight, and 'twas never used since, if you will 'tis at your service gallants, and tobacco too, 'tis right pudding I can tell you; a lady or two, took a pipe full or two at my hands, and praised it for the heavens, shall
I fill Flannius?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I thank you good Asinius for your love,
I seldom take that physic, 'tis enough
Having so much fool to take him in snuff.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Bubo read some book ▪ and give us leave▪ —

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Leave have you dear ningle, marry for reading any book I'll take my death upon't (As my ningle says) 'tis out of my element: no faith, ever since I felt one hit me ith' teeth that the greatest clerks are not the wisest men, could I abide to go to school, I was at as in presenti and left there: yet because I'll not be counted a worse fool than I am, I'll turn over a new leaf.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To see my fate, that when I dip my pen
In distilled roses, and do strive to drain,
Out of mine ink all gall; that when I weigh
Each syllable I write or speak, because
Mine enemies with sharp and searching eye ▪
Look through and through me, carving my poor labours
Like an anatomy: o heavens to see,
That when my lines are measured out as straight
As even parallels, 'tis strange that still,
Still some imagine they are drawn away.
The error is not mine, but in their eye,
That cannot take proportions.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Horace, Horace,
To stand within the shot of galling tongues,
Proves not your gilt, for could we write on paper,
Made of these turning 〈◊〉 of heaven, the clouds,
Or speak with angels tongues ▪ yet wise men know,
That some would sha●e the head, though saints should sing,
Some snakes 〈…〉, because they reborn with stings.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Do we not see fools laugh in heaven and mock
the maker's workmanship; be not you grieved
If that which you mould fair, upright and smooth,
Be screwed a wry, made crooked, lame and vile,
By racking comments, and calumnious tongues,
So to be bit it rankles not: for innocence
May with a feather brush off the foulest wrongs.
But when your dastard wit will strike at men
In corners, and in riddles fold the vices
Of your best friends, you must not take to heart,
If they take off all gild from their pills,
And only offer you the bitter core.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Crispinus.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Say that you have not sworn unto your paper,
To blot her white cheeks with her dregs and bottom
Of your friends private vices: say you swear
Your love and your allegiance to bright virtue
Makes you descend so low, as to put on
The office of an executioner,
Only to strike off the head of sin,
Where ere you find it standing,
Say you swear;
And make damnation parcel of your oath,
That when your lashing jests make all men bleed;
Yet you whip none. Court, city, country, friends,
Foes, all must smart alike; yet court, nor city,
Nor foe, nor friend, dare winch at you; great pity.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: If you swear, dam me Faninus, or Crispinus,
Or to the law (Our kingdom's golden chain)
To poet's dam me, or to player's dam me,
If I brand you, or you, tax you, scourge you:
I wonder then, that of five hundred, four hundred five,
Should all point with their fingers in one instant
At one and the same man?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Faninus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come, you cannot excuse it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hear me, I can —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You must daub on thick colours then to hide it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: We come like your physicians, to purge
Your sick and dangerous mind of her disease.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: In troth we do, out of our loves we come,
And not revenge, but if you strike us still,
We must defend our reputations:
Our pens shall like our swords be always sheathed,
Unless too much provoked, Horace if than
They draw blood of you, blame us not, we are men:
Come, let thy muse bear up a smoother sail,
'Tis the easiest and the basest art to rail,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Deliver me your hands, I love you both,
As dear as my own soul, prove me, and when
I shall traduce you, make me the scorn of men.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Enough, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What reads Asinius?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: By my troth here's an excellent comfortable book, it's most sweet reading in it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why, what does it smell of Bubo?

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Mass it smells of rose-leaves a little too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Then it must needs be a sweet book, he would fain perfume his ignorance.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: I warrant he had wit in him that penned it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: 'Tis good yet a fool will confess truth.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: The whoreson made me meet with a hard style in two or three places as I went over him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I believe thee, for they had need to be very low and easy styles of wit that thy brains go over.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: Where's this gallant? Morrow gentlemen: what's, this device done yet Horace?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: God's so, what mean you to let this fellow dog you into my chamber?

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: O, our honest captain, come, prithee let us see.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Why you bastards of nine whores, the Muses, why do you walk here in this gorgeous gallery of gallant inventions, with that whoreson poor lime and hair-rascal? why —

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O peace good Tucca, we are all sworn friends,

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Sworn, that Judas yonder that walks in rug, will dub you knights ath' post, if you serve under his band of oaths, the copper fact rascal will for a good supper out swear twelve dozen of grand juries.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: A pox on't, not done yet, and been about it three days?

sp.speaker: Hor●.
sp.p: By Jesu within this hour, save you captain Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Damn thee, thou thin bearded hermaphrodite, dam thee, I'll save myself for one I warrant thee, is this thy tub Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes captain this is my poor lodging.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Morrow captain Tucca, will you whiff this morning?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Art thou there goat's pizzle; no godamercy Cain I am for no whiffs I, come hither sheepskin-weavers s'foot thou lookest as though thou'dst begged out of a jail: draw, I mean not thy face (For 'tis not worth drawing) but draw near: this way, march, follow your commander you scoundrel: so, thou must run of an errand for me Mephistopheles.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: To do you pleasure captain I will, but whether

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
To hell, thou knowest the way, to hell my fire and brimstone, to hell; dost stare my sarsent-head at Newgate?
dost gloat? I'll march through thy Dunkirk's guts, for shooting jests at me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Dear captain but one word.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Out bench-whistler out, I'll not take thy word for a dagger pie: you brown-bread-mouth stinker, I'll teach thee to turn me into banks his horse, and to tell gentlemen I am a juggler, and can show tricks.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Captain Tucca, but half a word in your ear.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: No you starved rascal, thou'lt bite off mine ears then, you must have three or four suits of names, when like a lousy pediculous vermin thou'st but one suit to thy back: you must be called Asper, and Criticus, and Horace, thy title's longer a reading then the style a the big Turks: Asper, Criticus, Quintus, Horatius, Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Captain I know upon what even bases I stand, and therefore —

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Bases? would the rogue were but ready for me.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: Nay prithee dear Tucca, come you shall shake —

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Not hands with great hunks there, not hands, but I'll shake the gull-groper out of his tanned skin.

sp.speaker: Crisp. and Deme.
sp.p: For our sake captain, nay prithee hold.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Thou wrongest here a good honest rascal Crispinus, and a poor varlet Demetrius Fanninus (Brethren in thine own trade of poetry) thou sayest Crispinus' satin doublet is revealed out here, and that this penurious sneaker is out at elbows, go two my good full mouthed bandog, I'll ha' thee friends with both.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: With all my heart captain Tucca, and with you too, I'll lay my hands under your feet, to keep them from aching.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Can you have any more?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
Sayest thou me so, old coal come? do't than; yet 'tis no matter neither, I'll have thee in league first with these two
roly-polies : they shall be thy Damon's and thou their Pythias; Crispinus shall give thee an old cast satin suit, and Demetrius shall write thee a scene or two, in one of thy strong garlic comedies; and thou shalt take the guilt of conscience for't , and swear 'tis thine own old lad, 'tis thine own: thou never yet fellst into the hands of satin, didst?

sp.speaker: Hor
sp.p: Never captain I thank God.

sp.speaker: Tuc
sp.p: Go too, thou shalt now King Gorboduc, thou shalt, because I'll ha' thee damned, I'll ha' thee all in satin: Asper, Criticus, Quintus, Horatius, Flaccus, Crispinus shall do't, thou shalt do't, heir apparent of Helicon, thou shalt do't.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Mine ingle wear an old cast satin suit?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I wafer-face your ningle.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: If he carry the mind of a gentleman, he'll scorn it at's heels.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Marry muff, my man a gingerbread, wilt eat any small coal?

sp.speaker: As●.
sp.p: No captain, would you should well know it, great coal shall not fill my belly.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Scorn it, dost scorn to be arrested at one of his old suits?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No captain, I'll wear any thing.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I know thou wilt, I know thou'rt an honest low minded pigmy, for I ha' seen thy shoulders leapt in a player's old cast cloak, like a sly knave as thou art: and when thou ranst mad for the death of Horatio: thou borrowedst a gown of Roscius the stager, (That honest Nicodemus) and sentest it home lousy, didst not? Respond, didst not?

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: So, so, no more of this, within this hour —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: If I can sound retreat to my wits, with whom this leader is in skirmish, I'll end within this hour.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
What wilt end? wilt hang thyself now? has he not writ finis yet Jack? what will he be fifteen weeks about this cockatrice's egg too? has he not cackled yet? not
laid yet?

sp.speaker: Blum.
sp.p: Not yet, he swears he will within this hour.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: His wits are somewhat hard bound: the punk his muse has sore labour ere the whore be delivered: the poor saffron-cheek sunburnt Gipsy wants physic; give the hungry-face puddingpie-eater ten pills: ten shillings my fair Angelica, they 'Make his muse as yare as a tumbler.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: He shall not want for money if he'll write.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Go by Jeronimo, go by; and here, drop the ten shillings into this basin; do, drop, when Iackes he shall call me his Maecenas: besides, I'll dam up's oven-mouth for railing at's: so, is't right Jack? is't sterling? fall off now to the vanward of yonder four stinkers, and ask aloud if we shall go? the knight shall defray Jack, the knight when it comes to summa totalis, the knight, the knight. —

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, we'll leave you, shall we go captain? good Horace make some haste.

sp.speaker: Ho●.
sp.p: I'll put on wings.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: I never saw mine ingle so dashed in my life before.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes once Asinius.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Mass you say true, he was dashed worse once going (In a rainy day) with a speech to'th tiltyard, by god's lid has called him names, a dog would not put up, that had any discreation.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
Hold, hold up thy hand, I ha' seen the day thou didst not scorn to hold up thy golls: there's a soldier's spur-royal, twelve pence: stay, because I know thou canst not write without quicksilver; up again, this goll again, I give thee double press-money: stay, because I know thou hast a noble head, I'll divide my crown, o royal Porrex, there's a
teston more; go, thou and thy muse munch, do, munch; come my dear mandrake, if skeldring fall not to decay, thou shalt flourish: farewell my sweet Amadis de Gaul, farewell.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Dear captain.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Come Jack.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Nay captain stay, we are of your band.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: March fair then:

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Horace farewell, adieu Asinius

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Ningle let's go to some tavern, and dine together, for my stomach rises at this scurvy leather captain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No, they have choked me with mine own disgrace, which (Fools) I'll spit again even in your face.

div.stage: Enter sir Quintilian Shorthose, sir Adam, sir Vaughan, Minever with serving-men.

sp.speaker: Sir Quinti.
sp.p: Knaves, varlets, what lungs, give me a dozen of stools there.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Sesu pless us all in our five senses a piece, what mean ye sir Kintilian Sorthose to stand so much on a dozen stools, here be not preeches enough to hide a dozen stools, unless you wiss some of us preak his sins.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: I say sir Vaughan no shin shall be broken here ▪ what lungis, a chair with a strong back, and a soft belly, great with child; with a cushion for this reverend lady.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.p: God never gave me the grace to be a lady, yet I ha' been worshipped in my conscience to my face a thousand times, I cannot deny sir Vaughan, but that I have all implements, belonging to the vocation of a lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.p: I trust mistress Minever you have all a honest oman should have?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
Yes perdie, as my coach, and my fan, and a man
or two that 〈…〉 turn, and other things which I'd be loath every one should see, because they shall not be common, I am in manner of a lady in one point.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: I pray mistress Minevers, let us all see that point for our better understanding.

sp.speaker: Mi●●
sp.p: For I ha' some things that were fetched (I am sure) as far as some of the low countries, and I paid sweetly for them too, and they told me they were good for ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: And much good do't thy good heart fair widow with them.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I am fair enough to be a widow, sir Quintilian.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: In my soul and conscience, and well favoured enough to be a lady: here is sir quintilian Sorthose, and here is sir Adam Prickshaft, a sentleman of a very good brain, and well headed: you see he shoots his bolt seldom, but when Adam let's go, he hits: and here is sir Vaughan ap Rees, and I believe if God sud take us all from his mercy, as I hope he will not yet; we all three love you, at the bottom of our bellies, and our hearts: and therefore mistress Minever, if you please, you shall be knighted by one of us, whom you fall desire to put into your device and mind.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: One I must have sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir quin
sp.p: And one of us thou shalt have widow.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: One I must have, for now every one seeks to crow over me.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: By Sesu and if I find any crowing over you, and he were a cock (Come out as far as in Turkey's country) 'tis possible to cut his comb off.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I muse why sir Adam Prickshaft flies so far from us.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: I am in a brown study, my dear, if love should be turned into a beast, what beast he were fit to be turned into.

sp.speaker: Sir Quinti.
sp.p: I think sir Adam an ass, because of his bearing.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I think (Saving your reverence) sir Adam a puppy, for a dog is the most loving creature to a christian that is, unless it be a child.

sp.speaker: Sir Ad.
sp.p: No, I think if love should be turned away, and go to serve any beast, it must be an ape, and my reason —

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: Sir Adam, an ape? there's no more reason in an ape, than in a very plain monkey; for an ape has no tail, but we all know, or 'tis our duty to know, love has two tails; in my sudsment, if love be a beast, that beast is a bounce of reddis; for a bounce of reddis is wise meat without mutton, and so is love.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There's the yawning captain (Saving your reverence that has such a sore mouth) would one day needs persuade me, that love was a rebato; and his reason was (Saving your reverence) that a rebato was worn out with pinning too often; and so he said love was.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: And master captain Tucca said wisely too, love is a rebato indeed: a rebato must be poked; now many women wear rebates, and many that wear rebates —

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: Must be poked.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Sir Adam Prickshaft has hit the clout

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: The music speaks to us, we'll have a dance before dinner.

div.stage: Enter sir Walter Terrill, Caelestine, Blunt, Crispinus, and Demetrius, every one with a lady.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The king's at hand.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Father the king's at hand.
Music talk louder, that thy silver voice,
May reach my sovereign's ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p:
I pray do so, musicians bestir your singers, that
you may have us 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: His grace comes, a hall varlets, where be my men? blow, blow your cold 〈…〉 they sweat; tickle them till they sound again.

sp.speaker: Blun.
sp.p: Best go meet his grace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: Pray all stand bare, as well men as women: sir Adam is best you hide your head for fear your wise brains take key-cold: on afore sir Kintilian; sentlemen fall in before the ladies, in seemly order and fashion; so this is comely.

div.stage: Enter trumpets sounding, they go to the door, and meet the King and his train, and whilst the trumpets sound the King is welcomed, kisses the bride, and honours the bridegroom in dumb show.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay if your pleasures shrink at sight of us,
We shall repent this labour, mistress Bride
You that for speaking but one word today ▪
Must lose your head at night; you that do stand
Taking your last leave of virginity;
You that being well begun, must not be maid:
Win you the ladies, I the men will woo,
Ourself will lead my blushing bride with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.p: God bless your majesty, and send you to be along King William Rufus over us, when he sees his times and pleasures.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We thank you good sir Vaughan, we will take your meaning not your words.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Loud music there.

sp.speaker: Sir Vou.
sp.p: I am glad, our majesty will take any thing at my hands; my words trust in Sesu, are spoken between my soul and body together, and have neither felonies nor treasons about them, I hope.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Good words sir Vaughan, I prithee give us leave.

sp.speaker: Vaug.
sp.p: Good words sir Vaughan? that's by interpretation in English, you'd best give good words sir Vaughan: god and his ansells bless me, what ails his majesty to be so tedious and difficult in his right minds now, I hold my life that file rascal-rhymer Horace hath puzd and puzd above a hundred merry tales and lice, into his great and princely ears: by god and he use it, his being Phoebus priest cannot save him, if he were his sapline too I'd press upon his coxcomb: good lord bless me out of his majesty's cellar: King Williams, I hope 'tis none offences to make a supplication to god a mighty for your long life: for by shesu I have no meaning in't in all the world, unless rascals be here that will have your grace take chalk for she's, and unless Horace has sent lice to your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Horace, what's he sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Vaugh;
sp.p: As hard-favoured a fellow as your majesty has seen in a summer's day: he does pen, an't please your grace, toys that will not please your grace; 'tis a poet, we call them bards in our country, sings ballads and rhymes, and I was mighty sealous, that his ink which is black and full of gall, had brought my name to your majesty, and so lifted up your high and princely collar.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I neither know that Horace, nor mine anger, if as thou sayest our high and princely choler be up, we'll tread it down with dances; ladies lose not your men; fair measures must be tread, when by so fair a dancer you are led.

sp.speaker: Vaugh.
sp.p: Mistress Miniver:

sp.speaker: Min
sp.p: Perdie sir Vaughan I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Vaugh.
sp.p: Perdie by this Miniver cap, and according to his masesty's leave too, you sall be put in among these ladies, and dance ere long I trest in god, the saking of the seetes.

div.stage: They dance a strain, and whilst the others keep on, the King and Coelestine stay.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: That turn fair bride shows you must turn at night,
In that sweet dance which steals away delight.

sp.speaker: Cae●.
sp.l: Then pleasure is a thief, a fit, a fever:

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: True, he's the thief, but women the receiver.

div.stage: Another change; they fall in, the rest go on.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This change sweet maid, says you must change your life,
As virgins do.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Virgin's never change their life,
She that is wived a maid, is maid and wife.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But she that dies a maid; —

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Thrice happy then.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Leads apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Better lead apes than men.

div.stage: At this third change they end, and she meets the King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well met.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: 'Tis overtaken.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why fair sweet?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Women are overtaken when they meet;

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your blood speaks like a coward,

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: It were good,
If every maiden blush, had such a blood.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A coward blood, why whom should maidens fear?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Men, were maids cowards, they'd not come so near,
My lord the measure's done, I plead my duty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Only my heart takes measure of thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: Now by my hose I swear, that's no deep oath,
This was a fine sweet earthquake gently moved,
By the soft wind of whispering silks: come ladies,
Whose joints are made out of the dancing orbs,
Come, follow me, walk a cold measure now;
in the bride's chamber; your hot beauties melt,
Take every one her fan, give them their places,
And wave the Northern wind upon your faces.

div.stage: Celestine and all the ladies doing obeisance to the King, who only kisses her, exeunt, Shorthose manning them, the gallants stand aloof.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sir Walter Terrill.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My confirmed liege

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Beauty out of her bounty, thee hath lent,
More than her own with liberal extent.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What means my lord?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thy bride, thy choice, thy wife,
She that is now thy fathom, thy new world,
That brings thee people, and makes little subjects;
Kneel at thy feet, obey in every thing,
So every father is a private King.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My lord, her beauty is the poorest part,
Chiefly her virtues did endow my heart.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Do not backbite her beauties, they all shine,
Brighter on thee, because the beams are thine,
To thee more fair, to others her two lips
Show like a parted moon in thine eclipse;
That glance, which lovers amongst themselves devise,
Walks as invisible to other eyes:
Give me thine ear.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What means the King?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis a quaint strain.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou dar'st not what.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: She is too course an object for the court.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou dar'st not Wat: let tonight be tomorrow,

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: For she's not yet mine own.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou dar'st not Wat ▪

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My lord I dare, but —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But I see thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: This night.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yea, this night, tush thy mind repairs not,
The more thou talkest of night, the more thou dar'st not;
Thus far I tend, I would but turn this sphere,
Of ladies' eyes, and place it in the court,
Where thy fair bride should for the zodiac shine,
And every lady else sit for a sign.
But all thy thoughts are yellow, thy sweet blood
Rebels, thou'rt jealous Wat; thus with proud revels
To emulate the masking firmament,
Where stars dance in the silver hall of heaven,
Thy pleasure should be seasoned, and thy bed
Relish thy bride, but, but thou dar'st not Wat.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My lord I dare.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Speak that again.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Again kind Wat, and then I know thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare and will by that joint holy oath,
Which she and I swore to the book of heaven.
This very day when the surveying sun,
Ris like a witness to her faith and mine,
By all the loyalty that subjects owe
To majesty, by that, by this, by both,
I swear to make a double guarded oath,
This night untainted by the touch of man,
She shall a virgin come.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To court?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: To court.
I know I took a woman to my wife,
And I know women to be earthly moons,
That never shine till night, I know they change
Their orbs (Their husbands) and in sickish hearts,
steal to their sweet Endimions, to be cured
With better physic, sweeter diet drinks,
Then home can minister: all this I know
Yet know not all, but give me leave oh King,
To boast of mine, and say that I know none;
I have a woman but not such a one.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why, she's confirmed in thee; I now approve her,
If constant in thy thoughts who then can move her?

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.l: Will't please your highness take your place within,
The ladies attend the table.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I go good knight; what thy oath.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My lord,
My oath's my honour, my honour is my life,
My oath is constant, so I hope my wife.

div.stage: Enter Horace in his true attire, Asinius bearing his cloak.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: If you fly out ningle, here's your cloak; I think it rains too.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Hide my shoulders in't.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Troth so thou'dst need, for now thou art in thy p and cue; thou hast such a villainous broad back, that I warrant thou'rt able to bear away any man's jets in England.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: It's well sir, I ha' strength to bear yours methinks ; fore God you are grown a piece of a critist, since you fell into my hands: ah little rogue, your wit has picked up her crumbs pretty and well.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p:
Yes faith, I find my wit a the mending hand ningle; troth I do not think but to proceed poetaster next commencement, if I have my grace perfectly: every one that confer with me now, stop their nose in merriment and swear I smell somewhat of Horace; one calls me Horace's ape, another Horace's beagle, and such poetical names it passes. I was
but at barber's last day, and when he was rencing my face, did but cry out ▪ fellow thou mak'st me 〈◊〉 too long, and says he says hyee, master Asinius Bubo, you have e'en Horace's words as right as if he had spit them into your mouth.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Well, away dear Asinius, deliver this letter to the young gallant Druso, he that fell so strongly in love with me yesternight.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: It's a sweet musk-cod, a pure spiced-gull, by this feather I pity his ingenuities; but hast writ all this since ningle? I know thou hast a good running head and thou listest.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Foh come, your great bellied wit must long for every thing too; why you rook, I have a set of letters ready starched to my hands, which to any fresh suited gallant that but newly enters his name into my roll, I send the next morning, ere his ten o'clock dream has rise from him, only with clapping my hand to't, that my novice shall start, ho and his hair stand an end, when he sees the sudden flash of my writing; what you pretty diminutive rogue, we must have false fierce to amaze these spangle babies, these true heirs of ma. justice shallow.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: I would always have thee sauce a fool thus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Away, and, stay: here be epigrams upon Tucca, divulge these among the gallants; as for Crispinus, that crispin-ass and Fannius his play-dresser; who (To make the muses believe, their subjects' ears were starved and that there was a dearth of poesy) cut an innocent Moor i'th middle, to serve him in twice; and when he had done, made paul's work of it, as for these twins these poet - apes:
sp.l: Their mimic tricks shall serve
With mirth to feast our muse, whilst their own starve.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.p: Well ningle I'll trudge, but where's the rendezvous?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Well thought off, marry at sir Vaughan's lodging the Welsh knight, I have composed a love-letter for the gallants
worship, to his Rosamond: the second, mistress Miniver, because she does not think so soundly of his lame English as he could wish; I ha' gulled his knightship here to his face, yet have given charge to his winking understanding not to perceive it: nay gods so, away dear Bubo.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Muses birds the bees were hived and fled,
Us in our cradle, there by prophesying;
That we to learned ears should sweetly sing,
But to the vulgar and adulterate brain,
Should loathe to prostitute our virgin strain.
No, our sharp pen shall keep the world in awe,
Horace thy poesy, wormwood wreathes shall wear,
We hunt not for men's loves but for their fear.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: O sir Adam Prickshaft, you are a the bow hand wide, a long, yard I assure you: and as for suitors, truly they all go down with me, they have all one flat answer.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: All widow? not all, let sir Adam be your first man still.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: Widow, art stolen from table? I sir Adam,
Are you my rival? well, fly fair you're best;
The king's exceeding merry at the banquet,
He makes the bride blush with his merry words
That run into her ears; ah he's a wanton,
Yet I dare trust her, had he twenty tongues,
And every tongue a style of majesty,
Now widow, let me tell thee in thine ear,
I love thee widow, by this ring; nay wear it.

sp.speaker: Mineu.
sp.l: I'll come in no rings perdie, I'll take no gold.

div.stage: Enter sir Vaughan and Peter flash.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Master Peter flash, I will grope about sir Quintilian, for his terminations touching and considering you.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I thank your worship, for I have as good a stomach to your worship as a man could wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: I hope in God a mighty, I shall fill your stomach master Peter: what two upon one sentlemen; mistress Miniver, much good do't you sir Adam.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Sir Vaughan, have you dined well sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: As good seere as would make any hungry man (And a were in the vilest prison in the world) eat and he had any stomach: one word sir Quintilian in hugger-mugger ; here is a sentleman of yours, master Peter flash, is desirous to have his blue coat pulled over his ears; and —

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: No sir, my petition runs thus, that your worship would thrust me out of doors, and that I may follow sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Van.
sp.p: I can tell you master flash, and you follow me I go very fast, I think in my conscience, I am one of the lightest knights in England.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: It's no matter sir, the flashes have ever been known to be quick and light enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Sir Vaughan, he shall follow you, he shall dog you good sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Why then Peter flash I will set my four marks a year, and a blue coat upon you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: God a mercy to your worship, I hope you shall never repent for me.

sp.speaker: Sir vau
sp.p:
You bear the face of an honest man, for you blush passing well Peter, I will quench the flame out of your name,
and you shall be christened Peter Salamander.

sp.speaker: Peter flash.
sp.p: The name's too good for me, I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Are you come master Horace, you sent me the copy of your letters countenance, and I did write and read it; your wits truly have done very valiantly: 'tis a good inditements, you ha' put in enough for her ha' you not?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: According to my instructions.

sp.speaker: Sir Van.
sp.p: 'Tis passing well, I pray master Horace walk a little beside yourself, I will turn upon you incontinent.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: What gentleman is this in the mandilian, a soldier?

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: No, though he has a very bad face for a soldier, yet he has as desperate a wit as ever any scholar went to cuffs for; 'tis a sentleman poet, he has made rhymes called thalamimums, for m. pridegroom, on urd widow.

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: Is this he? welcome sir, you name? pray you walk not so stately, but be acquainted with me boldly; your name sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Quintus, Horacius, Flaccus.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Good master Flappus welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Mistress Miniver, one urde in your corner here; I desire you to break my arms here, and read this paper, you shall feel my minds and affections in it, at full and at large.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.p: I'll receive no love libels perdie, but by word a mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.p: By Sesu 'tis no libel, for here is my hand to it.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.p: I'll ha' no hand in it sir Vaughan, I'll not deal with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Va●.
sp.p: Why then widow, I'll tell you by word a mouth my devices.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Your devices come not near my mouth sir Vaughan perdie, I was upon a time in the way to marriage, but now I am turned a tother side, I ha' sworn to lead a single and simple life.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: She has answered you sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but at wrong weapons sir Adam; will you be an ass mistress Minivers?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: If I be you shall not ride me.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: A simple life! by Sesu 'tis the life of a fool, a simple life!

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: How now sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: My brains has a little fine qualm come under it, and therefore sir Adam, and sir Quintilian, and mistress Miniver caps God bye.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: Master Horace, your inventions do her no good in the universalities; yet here is two shillings for your wits; nay by Sesu you shall take it if't were more: yonder bald Adam's, is put my nose from his joint; but Adam I will be even to you: this is my cogitations, I will indite the ladies and Miniver caps to a dinner of plumbs, and I shall desire you m. Horace, to speak or rail; you can rail I hope in God a mighty.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You mean to speak bitterly:

sp.speaker: Sir Vaughan.
sp.p: Right, to spit bitterly upon baldness, or the thinness of hair; you sall eat down plumbs to sweeten your mouth, and here is a good ansell to defend you: Peter salamander follow me.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: With hue and cry and you will sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Come m, Horace, I will go pull out the ladies.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And I'll set out my wits, baldness the theme? My words shall flow high in a silver stream.

div.stage: Enter Tucca brushing off the crumbs.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Where's my most costly and sumptuous Shorthose ▪

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.p: Is the King risen from table captain Tucca?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: How? risen? no my noble Quintilian, Kings are greater men than we knights and cavaliers, and therefore must eat more than lesser persons; godamercy good dives for these crumbs: how now? has not friar Tucke dined yet? he falls so hard to that oyster-pie yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin
sp.p: Oyster-pie captain? ha ha, he loves her, and I love her and fear both shall go without her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Dost love her, my finest and first part of the mirror of knighthood? hang her she looks like a bottle of ale, when the cork flies out and the ale foams at mouth, she looks my good button-breech like the sign of Capricorn, or like Tyburn when it is covered with snow.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: All's one for that, she has a vizard in a bag, will make her look like an angel; I would I had her, upon condition, I gave thee this chain manly Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I? sayest thou so friskin? I have her ath' hip for some causes, I can sound her, she'll come at my beck.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Would I could sound her too noble commander.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Thou shalt do't; that lady ath' lake is thine sir Tristram, lend me thy chain, do, lend it, I'll make her take it as a token, I'll link her unto thee; and thou shalt wear her glove in thy worshipful hat like to a leather brooch; nay and thou mistrusts thy collar, be tied in't still.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: Mistrust captain no here 'tis, give it her if she'll take it, or wear it thyself , if she'll take me, I'll watch him well enough too.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: No more, I'll shoot away yonder Prickshaft, and then belabour her, and fly you after yonder cuckoo: dost hear me my noble goldfinch: —

sp.speaker: Sir Qui.
sp.p: No more.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
How do● thou my smug Bel-imperia? how dost thou? hands off my little bald Derrick, hands off: hark hither Susanna,
beware a these two wicked elders, shall I speak well or ill of thee?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Nay, e'en as you please captain, it shall be at your choice.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Why well said, my nimble Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.p: I hear her, I hear her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Art angry father time? art angry because I took mother-winter aside? I'll hold my life thou art struck with Cupid's bird-bolt, my little prick shaft, art? dost love that mother Mumblecrust, dost thou? dost long for that whim-wham?

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.p: Would I were as sure to lie with her, as to love her.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Have I found thee my learned dunce, have I found thee? If I might ha' my will, thou shouldst not put thy spoon into that bumble-broth (For indeed I'd taste her myself) no thou shouldst not; yet if her beauty blind thee, she's thine, I can do't, thou heardst her say e'en now, it should be at my choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ada.
sp.p: She did so, work the match and I'll bestow —

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Not a silk point upon me, little Adam she shall be thy Eve, for less than an apple; but send, be wise, send her some token, she's greedy, she shall take it, do, send, thou shalt stick in her (Prickshaft) but fend.

sp.speaker: Sir Adam.
sp.p: Here's a purse of gold, think you that will be accepted?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Go to, it shall be accepted, and 'twere but silver, when that flea-bitten Shorthose steps hence: vanish too, and let me alone with my grannam in Gutter-lane there, and this purse of gold do, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Quint.
sp.l: The King, god's lord, I do forget the King;
Widow, think on my words, I must be gone
To wait his rising, I'll return anon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ad.
sp.p: Stay sir Quintilian, I'll be a waiter too.

sp.speaker: Sir Quinti.
sp.p: Widow we'll trust that captain there with you.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Now, now, mother bunch how dost thou? what dost frown Queen Gwyniver? dost wrinkle? what made these pair of shittle-cocks here? what do they fumble for? I'll ha' none of these kites fluttering about thy carks, for thou shalt be my West Indyes, and none but trim Tucca shall discover thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Discover me? discover what thou canst of me.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: What I can? thou knowest what I can discover, but I will not lay thee open to the world,

sp.speaker: Min
sp.p: Lay me open to the world?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: No I will not my mouldy decayed Charingcross, I will not.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Hang thee patch-panel, I am none a thy Charing-cross: I scorn to be cross to such a scab as thou mak'st thyself.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: No, 'tis thou mak'st me so, my long Meg a Westminster, thou breed'st a scab, thou —

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I? dam thee filthy captain, dam thyself.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: My little devil a dow-gate, I'll dam thee, (Thou knowest my meaning) I'll dam thee up; my wide mouth at Bishopsgate.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Would I might once come to that damning.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Why thou shalt, my sweet dame Annis a clear thou shalt, for I'll drown myself in thee; ay, for thy love, I'll sink, ay, for thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: So thou wilt I warrant, in thy abominable sins; lord, lord, how many filthy words hast thou to answer for.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
Name one Madge-owlet, name one, I'll answer for none; my words shall be forth coming at all times, and shall answer for themselves; my nimble catamountain: they shall Sislie Bumtrinket, for I'll give thee none but sugar-candy
words, I will not puss: goody tripewife, I will not.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Why dost call me such horrible ungodly names then?

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: I'll name thee no more mother red-cap upon pain of death, if thou wilt Grimalkin, maggot a-pye I will not.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Would thou shouldst well know, I am no maggot, but a mere gentlewoman born.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: I know thou art a gentle, and I'll nibble at thee, thou shalt be my cap-a-maintenance, and I'll carry my naked sword before thee, my reverend lady lettuce-cap.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou shalt carry no naked swords before me to fright me, thou —

sp.speaker: Tuc
sp.p: Go too, let not thy tongue play so hard at hot-cockles; for, gammer Gurton, I mean to be thy needle, I love thee, I love thee, because thy teeth stand like the arches under London bridge, for thou'lt not turn satire and bite thy husband; no, come my little cub, do not scorn me because I go in stag, in buff, here's velvet too; thou seest I am worth thus much in bare velvet.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I scorn thee not, not I.

sp.speaker: Tuc
sp.p: I know thou dost not, thou shalt see that I could march with two or three hundred links before me, look here what? I could show gold too, if that would tempt thee, but I will not make myself a goldsmith's stall I; I scorn to go chained my lady ath' hospital, I do; yet I will and must be chained to thee.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: To me? why master captain, you know that I have my choice of three or four pair of knights, and therefore have small reason to fly out I know not how in a man of war.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p:
A man a war? come thou knowest not what a worshipful focation 'tis to be a captain's wife: three or four pair of knights? why dost hear Joane-a-bedlam, I'll enter into
bond to be dubbed by what day thou wilt ▪ when the next action is laid upon me, thou shalt be ladified.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You know I am offered that by half a dozen.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Thou shalt little Miniver, thou shalt, I'll ha' this frock turned into a foot-cloth; and thou shalt be carted, drawn I mean, coached, coached, thou shalt ride jigga-jog; a hood shall flap up and down here, and this sheepskin-cap shall be put off.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.p: Nay perdie, I'll put off my cap for no man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Wilt thou be proud little Lucifer? well, thou shalt go how thou wilt maid-marian; come, buss thy little Anthony now, now, my clean Cleopatria; so, so, go thy ways Alexis secrets, thou'st a breath as sweet as the rose, that grows by the bear-garden, as sweet as the proudest head a garlic in England: come, wilt march in, to the gentle folks?

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Nay truly captain you shall be my leader.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: I say Mary Ambree ▪ thou shalt march foremost,
Because I'll mark how broad thou'rt in the heels.

sp.speaker: Mini.
sp.l: Perdie, I will be set ath' last for this time.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Why then come, we'll walk arm in arm,
As though we were leading one another to Newgate.

div.stage: Enter Blunt, Crispinus, and Demetrius, with papers, laughing.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Mine's of a fashion, cut out quite from yours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mine has the sharpest tooth, yonder he is.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Captain Tucca.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: How now? I cannot stand to read supplications now

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: They're bitter epigrams composed on you by Horace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And dispersed amongst the gallants in several copies, by Asinius Bubo.

sp.speaker: Tuc,
sp.l: By that live eel? read, lege legito, read thou backe.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Tucca's grown monstrous, how? rich? that I fear,
He's to be seen for money everywhere .

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Why true, shall not I get in my debts, nay and the rogue write no better I care not, farewell black Jack farewell.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: But captain, here's a nettle.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Sting me, do.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Tucca's exceeding tall and yet not high,
He fights with skill, but does most vilely lie.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Right, for here I lie now, open, open ▪ to make my adversary come on; and then sir, here am I in's bosom: nay and this be the worst, I shall hug the poor honest face-maker, I'll love the little atheist, when he writes after my commendation, another whip? come yerk me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Tucca will bite, how? grown satirical,
No, he bites tables, for he feeds on all.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: The whoreson cloven-foot devil in man's apparel lies,
There stood above forty dishes before me today,
That I ne'er touched, because they were empty.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I am witness young gentlemen to that.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.p: Farewell stinkers, I smell thy meaning screech-owl, I do though I stop my nose: and sirrah poet, we'll have thee untrust for this; come, mother mum-pudding, come.

div.stage: Trumpets sound a flourish, and then a sennet: enter King with Calestine, sir Walter Terrill, sir Quintilian, sir Adam, Blunt and other ladies and attendants: whilst the trumpets sound the King takes his leave of the bridegroom, and sir Quintilian, and last of the bride.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My song of parting doth this burden bear;
A kiss the ditty, and I set it here.
Your lips are well in tune, strung with delight,
By this fair bride remember soon at night:
Sir Walter.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My liege lord, we all attend,
The time and place.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Till then my leave commend.

div.stage: They bring him to the door: enter at another door sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Ladies ▪ I am to put a very easy suit upon you all, and to desire you to fill your little pellies at a dinner of plums behind noon; there be suckets, and marmalades, and merchants, and other long white plums that fain would kiss your delicate and sweet lips; I indite you all together, and you especially my lady pride; what do you say for your selles? for I indite you all.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: I thank you good sir Vaughan, I will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Say gentlewomen will you stand to me too?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We'll sit with you sweet sir Vaughan.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: God a mighty pless your faces, and make your peauties last, when we are all dead and rotten: — you all will come.

sp.speaker: 1 lady.
sp.p: All will come.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Pray God that Horace be in his right wits to rail now.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come lady, you shall be my dancing guest.
To tread the maze of music with the rest.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll lead you in.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.l: A maze is like a doubt:
'Tis easy to go in, hard to get out.

sp.speaker: Blum.
sp.l: We follow close behind.

sp.speaker: Philoca.
sp.l: That measure's best.
Now none marks us, but we mark all the rest.

div.stage: Exeunt all saving sir Quintilian, Caelestine, and sir Walter Terrill.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Father, and you my bride; that name today,
Wife, comes not till tomorrow: but omitting
This interchanging of languages; let us think
Upon the King and night and call our spirits
To a true reckoning; first to arm our wits
With complete steel of judgement, and our tongs,
With sound artillery of phrases: then
Our bodies must be motions; moving first
What we speak: afterwards, our very knees
Must humbly seem to talk, and suit out speech;
For a true furnished courtier hath such force,
Though his tongue faints, his very legs discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir Quin:
sp.l: Son Terrill, thou hast drawn his picture right,
For he's no full-made courtier, nor well strung,
That hath not every joint stuck with a tongue.
Daughter, if ladies say, that is the bride, that's she,
Gaze thou at none, for all will gaze at thee.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Then, o my father must I go? O my husband
Shall I then go? O myself, will I go?

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I will, but give me leave,
To say I may not, nor I ought not, say not
Still, I must go, let me entreat I may not.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You must and shall, I made a deed of gift,
And gave my oath unto the King, I swore
By thy true constancy.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Then keep that word
To swear by, oh let me be constant still.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What shall I cancel faith, and break my oath?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: If breaking constancy thou breakest them both.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thy constancy no evil can pursue.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I may be constant still, and yet not true.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: As thus, by violence detained,
They may be constant still, that are constrained.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Constrained? that word weighs heavy, yet my oath
Weighs down that word; the King's thoughts are at odds,
They are not even balanced in his breast;
The King may play the man with me; nay more,
Kings may usurp; my wife's a woman; yet
'Tis more than I know yet, that know not her,
If she should prove mankind, 'twere rare, fie, fie,
See how I lose myself, amongst my thoughts,
Thinking to find myself; my oath, my oath,

sp.speaker: Sir Quin.
sp.l: I swear another, let me see ▪ by what,
By my long stocking, and my narrow skirts,
Not made to sit upon, she shall to court.
I have a trick, a charm ▪ that shall lay down
The spirit of lust, and keep thee undeflowered;
Thy husband's honour saved, and the hot King,
Shall have enough too ▪ come, a trick, a charm.

sp.speaker: Cae●.
sp.l: God keep thy honour safe, my blood from harm.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Come, my sick-minded bride, I'll teach thee how,
To relish health a little: taste this thought,
That when mine eyes served loves commission,
Upon thy beauties I did seize on them.
To a King's use; cure all thy grief with this,
That his great seal was graven upon this ring,
And that I was but steward to a King.

div.stage: A banquet set out: enter sir Vaughan, Horace, Asinius Bubo, lady Petula, Dicache, Philocalia, mistress Miniver and Peter flash.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: Ladies and sentlemen, you are almost all welcome, to this sweet nuntions of plums.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.p:
Almost all sir Vaughan: why to which of us are
you so niggardly, that you cut her out but a piece of welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Vaugh.
sp.p: My interpretations is that almost all are welcome, because I indicted a brace or two more that is not come, I am sorry my lady pride is not among you.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: 'Slid, he makes hounds of us ningle, a brace quoth 'a?

sp.speaker: Sir Vaug.
sp.p: Peter salamanders draw out the pictures of all the joint stools, and ladies sit down upon their wooden faces.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I warrant sir, I'll give every one of them a good stool.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Master Horace, master Horace, when I pray to God, and desire in hypocritenesses that bald sir Adam's were here, then, then, then begin to make you rails at the poverty and beggarly want of hair.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Leave it to my judgment.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: M. Bubo sit there, you and I will think upon our ends at the tables: m. Horace, put your learned body into the midst of these ladies; so 'tis no matter to speak graces at nuntions, because we are all past grace since dinner.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Mass I thank my destiny I am not past grace, for by this hand full of caraways, I could never abide to say grace.

sp.speaker: Dica.
sp.p: Mistress Miniver, is not that innocent gentleman a kind of fool?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Why do you ask madam?

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.p: Nay for no harm, I ask because I thought you two had been of acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I think he's within an inch of a fool.

sp.speaker: Dicach.
sp.p: Madam Philocalia, you sit next that spare gentleman, would you heard what mistress Miniver says of you.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p: Why what says she madam Dicache.

sp.speaker: Dica.
sp.p: Nay nothing, but wishes you were married to that small timbered gallant.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.p:
Your wish and mine are twins, I will so too for
then I should be sure to lead a merry life.

sp.speaker: Asini.
sp.p: Yes faith lady, I'd make you laugh, my bolts now and then should be soon shot; by these comfits, weed let all slide.

sp.speaker: Petu.
sp.p: He takes the sweetest oaths that ever I heard a gallant of his pitch swear; by these comfits, and these caraways, I warrant it does him good to swear.

sp.speaker: Asin.
sp.l: Yes faith 'tis meat and drink to me.
I am glad lady Petula (By this apple) that they please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Peter salamander's wine, I beseech you master Asinius Bubo, not to swear so deeply, for there comes no fruit of your oaths; here ladies, I put you all into one corners together, you shall all drink of one cup.

sp.speaker: Asi.
sp.p: Peter I prithee fill me out too.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I'd fling you out too and I might ha' my will, a pox of all fools.

sp.speaker: Sir Vau.
sp.p: Mistress Minivers, pray be lusty, would sir Adams Prickshaft stuck by you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Who, the bald knight sir Vaughan?

sp.speaker: Sir vau
sp.p: The same m. Horace, he that has but a remnant or parcel of hair, his crown is clipped and pared away; methinks 'tis an excellent quality to be bald; for and there stuck a nose and two nyes in his pate, he might wear two faces under one hood.

sp.speaker: As●.
sp.p: As God save me la, if I might ha' my will, I'd rather be a bald gentleman than a hairy; for I am sure the best and tallest yeomen in England have bald heads: methinks hair is a scurvy lousy commodity.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Bubo, herein you blaze your ignorance.

sp.speaker: Sir vau
sp.p: Pray stop and fill your mouths, and give m. Horace all your ears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For ▪ if of all the bodies parts, the head
Be the most royal: if discourse, wit, judgement,
